column5: I thought about trying this too, instead of tying a 3 way swivel on. More of a traditional rigging for drop shotting. I wasn't sure if the mono would hold up on the upper lure if two fish did decide to bite. Seems like this would be a good way to keep the line tight on the upper fly / bait.

I've done it - I called it the Mojo Rig. I do think it might work pretty well with artificial bait, but plan to lose a lot of bait if you are using minnows. I still caught most of my fish on the jig, but I did catch a few on the upper hook. My minnow would always be gone on the upper hook when I would either swing and miss or catch a fish on the jig. I got bored with it and stopped. It does sound good in theory though, and I have caught walleyes on the true drop shot rig.

I thought I would try a different technique as an experiment this year on Ontario. I like to drop shot for bass. I thought I would try a variation of this for walleye. My plan is to use my typical 3/8oz jig with a plastic that I hop along the bottom. About 18" up I'm going to tie a tri-turn swivel, and run a bucktail walleye fly on 8 to 10" of line. Unweighted fly or perhaps a plastic leech on a light hook. Drifting along, I'll bounce the jig on the bottom and the fly should drift along above it. I checked the Ontario fishing regulations, and I believe that this is legal. From what I can tell, you can have 4 hooks in the water at once, but only one line. They do allow an Alabama / umbrella, as long as there are only 4 hooks on it. I think I'll do a little more checking to be sure before I attempt this, but it appears legal. Should be an effective way to prospect. Plus, it would be a hoot to catch two at once :-)
As long as it falls into the legal category..."to each their own" I guess. One barbless hook is the only way I roll.

Hello, I tried this technique as I also believed it was legal as long as I stay under the maximum number of shanks and hooks. More importantly I had terrible time getting hook ups on the primary hook (suspended one). The line was tight to the heavy (dropper) jig, but the suspended one I keep missing bites and losing bait. My top hook of choice was a floating jig with a minnow or leach. Make sure you are within the rules wherever you try this as I'm sure the price for breaking the rules would be stiff. B-

Got an official response from Ontario NRISC (NDMNRF) Here was their response : "Hello: Thank you for your inquiry.What you have described would be legal. You can have 1 main line and you could have up to 4 separate line branching from the main line with a hook attached to each line and be legal as long as you don’t have more than 4 hooks in total attached to the main line."
